text: Case briefing is the best way to prepare for a law school class. For each of your classes, you will be assigned cases from different courts around the country. (NarrativeText)

Learning from cases is the main method of education within law schools in the United States. Professors will ask you questions about the cases that were assigned for that day to prepare best for class. It helps digest and understand case materials better before discussing them with peers or a professor (NarrativeText).

It is critical to prepare your own concise, informative briefs of each given assignment which would include all the required information as provided in the course syllabus such as Case name, facts, procedural history etc. and be well-prepared before class for discussions (NarrativeText).

Each case comprises seven main components namely - 'case name', 'facts' of the case,'procedural history','issue raised in court based on said issue a ruling is made or judgment/ verdict rendered. This decision could either be unanimous, majority ruled by Supreme Court justices (Reasoning) and this rule becomes binding precedent for future cases involving similar circumstances as described within the case facts of that particular legal matter being discussed in court proceedings.'(NarrativeText)

Your professors may have specific focus on different components like 'procedural history' or others. Depending upon professor’s emphasis and his teaching style, you need to understand which component he values more as the course progresses.
The trial court dismissed the plaintiff's claim. (Page: Not provided)
